scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of the team members, Alex, says, 'This is impossible! We can't get this done in time.' You responded by suggesting breaking the tasks into smaller parts. The team seemed somewhat relieved but still on edge. Monica and Bob exchange concerned looks. Monica then speaks up, 'Even with smaller tasks, the deadline is still too tight.' Bob, looking frustrated, adds, 'I don't think anyone here believes we can actually pull this off.' You responded by asking if anyone has a better idea or a more efficient way to get this done, otherwise, to get back to work. The team resumes work, but the tension is palpable. Monica sighs loudly and says, 'I really don't see how we can manage this.' You noticed Bob shaking his head and muttering, 'This is just setting us up for failure.' You addressed the negativity directly and opened the floor for specific concerns. Bob raises his hand and says, 'I think we need more resources or more time to make this feasible.' You acknowledged the team's concerns and proposed a practical solution by suggesting to ask for a deadline extension. The team seemed to consider this option but was still uncertain. [Monica] and [Bob] exchange looks again.
scenes.description: [Monica] leans forward and says, 'Even if we get an extension, we still need to figure out how to work more efficiently.' Bob adds, 'And what if they say no to the extension?'

options.text: I understand your concerns. Let's focus on streamlining our processes and improving our efficiency with what we have.
options.analysis: You encouraged the team to stay focused and make the best use of their resources, showing good self-regulation and motivational skills.

options.text: If they say no, we'll have to work with what we've got. Let's outline our most critical tasks and prioritize accordingly.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the possible setback and suggested a practical approach, demonstrating good empathy and emotional perception.

options.text: We can't expect everything to go perfectly, but we need to stay positive and focus on what we can control.
options.analysis: You addressed the concerns and encouraged the team to focus on controllable factors, showing moderate emotional perception and empathy.
